title: University of Benghazi reopens after three years
description:
(4 Aug 2017) LEADIN:
Following years of closure, the University of Benghazi in Libya has once more opened its doors.
STORYLINE:
The University of Benghazi has been badly affected by the ongoing instability in Libya.
What once were proud and beautiful buildings are damaged, possibly beyond repair.
Conflict raged in the city in 2014 between the Libyan national army and armed groups. The fighting took a heavy toll on the university, forcing students to relocate to other buildings in the city.
The University of Benghazi is one of the largest integrated universities in Libya.  It was founded in 1955 and contains more than 20 faculties.
More than 20-thousand students are enrolled at the university.
Now the university has opened its doors again and the students are flooding back.
Some of the faculties such as Law and Economics have been cleaned up and are ready to allow students back in.
Law student Fatima Al-Shobaki says she is delighted that faculty is open again. 
The Dean of the Faculty of Law, Mustafa Jamali, says a lot of work has gone into getting the building ready for students.
"The college students have made an extraordinary effort to contribute to the maintenance and cleaning of the college. They have given important and fundamental support and helped raise our morale for the return (of students)," he says.
But some other departments, such as Engineering, are still being tidied up.
Many students have volunteered to help get this done.
Engineering student Adnan Bouhdma says they are slowly tidying up many of the buildings at the university.
He says there are many people getting involved with the clean up.
"So we contacted our colleagues and there were not many at first, but thank God, now it has increased as you see. There are other colleagues who are cleaning the other side over there," he says.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/81813ee1f9fbb411f7f2afcd4b069888 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork
